title: PZ Cussons profits slide on Nigerian turmoil
text:

Sat, Jul 18, 2015, 21:58 BST - UK Markets closed PZ Cussons profits slide on Nigerian turmoil By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 1 hour 50 minutes ago 358.60 -2.50 
Consumer goods conglomerate behind Carex handwash and St Tropez self-tan brands expected to report a dip in sales after political uncertainty in Nigeria, its biggest market 
Soaring sales of fake tan in Britain have failed to offset the turmoil caused by Nigerian elections for PZ Cussons (LSE: PZC.L - news ) , which is set to report a 12pc fall in profits this week. 
The maker of Imperial Leather soap and Original Source shower gel counts the African country as its biggest market, where it sells the number one soap, powdered milks and fridges. 
Sales are expected to fall 5pc to £816.3m alongside a drop in profits to £108.7m from the year before. 
However, the disappointing figures will be partly balanced by PZ Cussons’ UK business, which is expected to have been boosted by its St Tropez tanning range. 
PZ Cussons makes Imperial Leather soaps and shower gels 
The brand, fronted by the supermodel Kate Moss, recently launched new in-shower fake tan product which sold out within days of its launch, prompting the company to produce an extra one million bottles. 
Last month the consumer group, nicknamed a “mini Unilever” by analysts, updated the City and said that the Nigerian naira exchange rate has stabilised following a 25pc plunge in value in the second half of the year. 
PZ Cussons said that the elections, which saw former military ruler Muhammadu Buhari replace Goodluck Jonathan , resulted in a relatively short loss of trading days but uncertainties remained. Analysts at HSBC downgraded the company to a “hold” last week because of “the unclear outlook in Nigeria”. 
Nigeria's President Goodluck Jonathan (L) presents a gift to president-elect Muhammadu Buhari at the presidential villa in Abuja 
Around 50pc of PZ Cusson’s personal care brands, which also include Sanctuary toiletries, are now sold in high street discount chains such as Poundland and B&M. Bargain hunters have prompted the company to develop a new low-cost range. 
The company is also expected to reveal the extent of the impact on the business from the economic crisis in Greece where it is the biggest olive oil brand. 
Brandon Leigh, finance director, told The Daily Telegraph earlier this month that its Greek arm would be fairly resilient as olive oil was essential to the Greeks’ diet and the last thing that they would cut from their shopping baskets. 
However, the business, which sells olive oil and feta cheese under its Minerva brand and dates back to the 1900s, is expected to have limited impact as it only accounts for 3pc of overall sales.
